Situation1: They are asked to guide a mentee preparing for a critical career advancement opportunity.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story: I glanced at the clock on the dashboard, my phone pressed to my ear on speaker. My mentee’s voice trembled as she described her anxiety about the big interview tomorrow. As her mentor, I knew she needed reassurance, guidance—my full attention. I wanted to encourage her, help her see her strengths, and offer last-minute advice that could make all the difference. But as I turned the corner, orange cones forced traffic into a single lane. Up ahead, a school zone sign flashed, and children clustered near the curb, their laughter piercing through the hum of engines. As a taxi driver, I was expected to drive defensively, obey every law, and keep my passengers and those children safe. My mentee’s words faded into the background as I gripped the wheel, heart pounding. I felt torn—should I focus on her, risking distraction, or cut her off, risking her confidence? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
